qas.question: What do mutations in a gene sequence lead to?

answers.text: encode slightly different versions of a protein

qas.question: What does "having a gene" or a "good gene" typically refer to?

answers.text: having a different allele of the gene
natural selection or survival of the fittest of the alleles

context: Genes can acquire mutations in their sequence, leading to <a0_0>different variants, known as alleles<a0_0/>, in the population. These alleles <a1_0>encode slightly different versions of a protein<a1_0/>, which cause <a2_0>different phenotype traits<a2_0/>. Colloquial usage of the term "having a gene" (e.g., "good genes," "hair colour gene") typically refers to <a3_0>having a different allele of the gene<a3_0/>. Genes evolve due to <a4_0>natural selection or survival of the fittest of the alleles<a4_0/>.
